title: Education
section: Master in Data Science - University of British Columbia (September 2024 - June 2025)
text:
Master in Data Science - University of British Columbia (September 2024 - June 2025)

I am currently pursuing my Master’s in Data Science at the University of British Columbia, driven by my passion for statistics and machine learning. I was drawn to this program because of my strong interest in solving complex real-world problems using data-driven insights—particularly in healthcare and finance.
Throughout the program, I’ve worked on collaborative projects, applying these skills to real-world datasets. You can find more details on my Projects page.

Programming & Tools

Python, R, SQL, Git, Bash, Docker, GitHub Workflows



Data Engineering

Databases (SQL), Data Pipelines, Cloud Computing, Web & Cloud Tools



Machine Learning

Supervised Learning (Logistic Regression, Decision Trees, SVM, XGBoost)
Unsupervised Learning (K-Means, PCA, Hierarchical Clustering)
Feature Engineering, Model Evaluation, Advanced ML Topics



Statistics & Experimentation

Descriptive & Inferential Statistics, Probability, Hypothesis Testing
Regression Analysis, Causal Inference, Experimental Design



Visualization & Communication

Data Visualization (Matplotlib, Seaborn, ggplot2)
Communication for Stakeholders, Argumentation & Storytelling



Capstone
I will be working on a capstone project with an industry partner to tackle a real-world business challenge using data science.


Sports Representative
In addition to my coursework, I served as the Sports Representative for the MDS cohort, organizing recreational events such as volleyball, water wars, skating nights, and a ski trip. These experiences strengthened my leadership, event planning, and team-building skills.

title: Education
section: Bachelor’s in Biomedical Sciences - Trent University (September 2020 - April 2024)
text:
Bachelor’s in Biomedical Sciences - Trent University (September 2020 - April 2024)

I completed my undergraduate degree in Biomedical Sciences with a Minor in Mathematics at Trent University. My academic journey was shaped by my dual passion for biology and mathematics, which led me to a degree that merges both disciplines. During my degree, I explored various disciplines, gaining a solid understanding of biological, chemical, and mathematical principles relevant to data science and healthcare analytics.

Academic Achievements

Awarded a Renewable Entrance Scholarship for maintaining a high academic standing (90-95% entry average).
Consistently placed on the Dean’s Honour Roll, earning recognition each semester.
Achieved a perfect 100% in two advanced statistics courses—despite entering with no prior statistical background.



Mathematics & Statistics

Calculus I & II, Linear Algebra, Euclidean Geometry
Ordinary Differential Equations (ODEs), Discrete Structures
Probability & Applied Statistics, Linear Programming



Biomedical Sciences

Human & Animal Anatomy and Physiology
Histology, Molecular Biology, Cell Biology, Genetics
Microbiology, Biomedical Ethics, Evolution, Nutrition
Psychology & Neuroscience



Chemistry

Introductory Chemistry, Organic Chemistry
Protein Chemistry & Enzymology, Biochemistry



Finance & Accounting

Financial Accounting, Global Finance

title: Natural Antibiotics Study
text:
Overview
This self-led experimental project explored the antibacterial properties of honey and tea tree oil against gram-negative bacteria. I independently designed and conducted a full experiment — from forming a research question to analyzing the results using R — applying both experimental methods and statistical modeling to evaluate the effectiveness of natural antibiotics.


Project Goals & Contributions

Designed the entire experimental setup including controls, treatments, and randomized testing
Collected and cultured bacterial samples from real biological sources
Prepared varying concentrations (0%, 50%, 100%) of honey and tea tree oil
Controlled environmental conditions across two locations (bedroom and basement)
Performed bacterial colony counting (CFU) and logged observations across 24 test samples
Wrote and executed R code for data wrangling, model fitting, ANOVA, interaction plots, and residual diagnostics
Used lm() models, contrasts, and Tukey tests to assess significance of location, antibiotic, and concentration




Technical and Scientific Implementation

R (base, gmodels) for modeling, plotting, and contrast analysis

Experimental Design principles (randomization, controls, blocks)

Data Wrangling and exploratory data visualization

Hypothesis Testing & Interpretation using ANOVA and linear models




Key Takeaways

Applied real-world data science methods to a biology problem from scratch
Practiced designing reproducible experiments and manually collecting primary data
Developed comfort with statistical modeling, including multi-factor ANOVA and model diagnostics
Strengthened skills in scientific writing, research methodology, and R scripting

While results did not find statistically significant differences between treatments, this project deepened my understanding of experimental variability, data limitations, and the value of a clear, reproducible workflow. It showcased my ability to design, execute, and interpret full-stack analytical work — a skill I bring to all my data science projects.

Final Report


⬅ Back to Projects

title: Health Science Calculator
text:
Health Science Calculator is a Python package designed to provide accurate and efficient health metric calculations. This project was developed as part of a collaborative effort using best practices in software engineering, automation, and version control to ensure code quality, maintainability, and scalability. This package was designed to be useful for health professionals, researchers, and fitness enthusiasts.
Collaborators: Akosua, Jiayi Li, Tengwei Wang





Developed a modular Python package for health-related calculations.
Implemented core functions for BMI, BMR, TDEE, and unit conversion.
Integrated Pytest for automated testing, achieving 100% test coverage.
Implemented GitHub Actions for CI/CD, enabling automated testing and deployment.
Published the package to PyPI (pip install healthsciencecalculator).
Designed API documentation using Sphinx and Read the Docs.
Collaborated using Git workflows (branching, merging, pull requests).





This package includes the following key functions:

get_tdee(): Calculates Total Daily Energy Expenditure (TDEE) based on BMR and activity level.

get_bmi(): Computes Body Mass Index (BMI) and classifies users (underweight, normal, overweight, obese).
get_bmr(): Uses the Harris-Benedict equation to compute Basal Metabolic Rate (BMR).

unit_convert(): Converts between metric and imperial units for weight, height, temperature, and volume.

Each function was carefully tested to ensure accuracy and reliability.




This project strengthened my skills in:

Software Development: Object-oriented programming, API design.

Data Processing & Analytics: Structured data handling, validation.
Automation & CI/CD: GitHub Actions, Pytest, automated deployments.
Collaborative Development: Git version control, team coordination.
Technical Communication: API documentation, user guides.

By developing this package, I gained experience in building scalable and well-tested software solutions, with direct applications in data science, AI, and healthcare analytics.
Github Repository

⬅ Back to Projects

title: The Data Science Starter Kit - Blog
text:
The Data Science Starter Kit Blog is a beginner-friendly resource designed to help aspiring data scientists navigate fundamental concepts and practical tools.
This project aims to simplify the learning process by offering step-by-step tutorials, code examples, and educational content to build a strong foundation in data science.




Through this project, I strengthened my skills in:

Technical Communication – Writing clear, structured explanations for data science concepts.
Software Development & Best Practices – Using GitHub for version control and project management.
Educational Content Creation– Designing learning materials for data science beginners.
Community Engagement – Promoting knowledge-sharing through accessible online resources.

Github Repository

title: NYPD Arrest Tracker App
text:
The NYPD Arrest Tracker App is a collaborative data science project aimed at providing NYC government executives with a unified dashboard for monitoring arrest statistics** across the city.
The goal of this project was to create an interactive and data-driven tool that allows policymakers to track trends, analyze arrest data, and make evidence-based decisions regarding law enforcement and public safety initiatives.
Collaborators: Michael Gelfand, Michael Hewlett









Designing a responsive sidebar with custom filters for crime type, precinct vs. borough, and date ranges
Creating the calendar-based date selector to allow time-based analysis
Improving dashboard performance with function caching using Flask-Caching
Cleaning and transforming geographic and demographic datasets using pandas and GeoPandas
Coordinating version control with GitHub issues, branches, and pull requests
Writing documentation including the final README and setup instructions








Through this project, I gained experience in:

Data Engineering – Processing large-scale NYC arrest records.
Data Visualization – Developing interactive dashboards for government use.
Policy Analytics – Using data science to drive public safety decisions.
Public Sector UI/UX – Creating user-friendly tools for non-technical stakeholders.

This project highlights the real-world impact of data science in law enforcement and public policy.
Github Repository
Explore the Dashboard

⬅ Back to Projects

title: Bank Marketing Prediction
text:
The Bank Marketing Prediction collaborative Project applies machine learning techniques to enhance bank marketing strategies by predicting whether a customer will subscribe to a term deposit based on demographic and campaign-related data.
The goal was to develop a predictive model that helps banks optimize resource allocation, minimize marketing costs, improve customer conversion rates This project incorporated end-to-end data science workflows, data preprocessing, and model evaluation to identify the most effective approach for targeted marketing.
Collaborators: Fazeeia Mohammad, Rong Wan




This project focused on developing a scalable and automated machine learning workflow to improve marketing strategies. The main objectives and contributions include:

Predicting Customer Subscription Behavior: Building predictive models to classify customer responses based on demographic and campaign-related data.

Optimizing Marketing Strategies: Identifying patterns in customer responses to enhance targeting and reduce marketing costs.

Building a Fully Reproducible Machine Learning Pipeline: Developing an end-to-end pipeline using Python, Jupyter Notebooks, and GitHub Actions.

Automating Data Processing & Model Training: Implementing a structured workflow using Click, Docker, and Makefiles to ensure automation.

Enhancing Model Interpretability: Using feature importance analysis to provide insights into the key factors influencing customer behavior.

Effectively Communicating Insights: Presenting findings through structured reports and data-driven presentations to stakeholders.





Data Preprocessing & Feature Engineering

Cleaned, standardized, and structured raw customer data.

Applied feature scaling and categorical encoding.

Handled missing values and class imbalance issues to improve model performance.

Machine Learning Models & Performance Evaluation

Built Logistic Regression and Decision Tree Classifier models.

Tuned hyperparameters to improve precision, recall, and overall accuracy.

Compared models based on accuracy, precision, recall, and F1 score.

Identified trade-offs between false positives and false negatives for better marketing decisions.

Automating Workflows with Docker & Makefile

Dockerized the project for reproducibility and easy deployment.

Used Makefiles to automate data processing, model training, and reporting.

Running the Analysis

Set up a Docker container to allow for easy execution of the project.

Automated data processing and model training using Makefile workflows.

Generated structured reports detailing model performance and business recommendations.





To ensure stakeholders could easily interpret and apply model insights, we developed a presentation that:

Simplified complex machine learning concepts.
Highlighted the most impactful findings from model evaluation.

Provided clear, data-driven recommendations to enhance marketing strategies.

By combining technical depth with actionable insights, this presentation helped decision-makers understand how AI-driven marketing could improve customer outreach and conversion rates.




This project strengthened my skills in:

Building scalable ML models – End-to-end data science workflows.
Data Engineering & Pipelines – Automating data processing and model training.

Version Control & Collaboration – Managing contributions via GitHub.

Effective Communication – Presenting data insights in a structured and compelling format.

Github Repository
Final Report
Presentation Slides

⬅ Back to Projects
